entry.title: Cant reuse variable within same automation in SAP BPA
entry.content:
Hi all, we are using automation scenario where certain variant is selected in sap gui (row 0 for example) and result of this is sent to defined users. Both variant row and email recipients are later defined in environment variables. In IRPA (predecessor of BPA) these variables were always defined when creating scenario trigger, so it was possible to define them for each new trigger. Now in BPA this seems to be not working as variables need to be defined when deploying the scenario. 

I wonder if this functionality is gone or is there any other approach how to leverage same scenario and run it with another variables? So far this seems to be like step beck as I would have to clone the same scenario and deploy it only because of another variables.

Many thanks for your answer.

entry.title: Unable to Execute ‚ÄúAdvance Return for Tax on Sales/Purchases‚Äù in Background
entry.content:
While executing the GST report using the Fiori app ‚ÄúCreate Advance Return for Tax on Sales/Purchases‚Äù, we noticed that the option ‚ÄúExecute in Background‚Äù is greyed out and cannot be selected.

In the ECC system, there was an option to process the batch input session immediately or execute the report directly in background.

However, in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, we can only execute the report interactively. When the batch input session is created, it can be viewed under the app ‚ÄúBatch Input Sessions in My Area‚Äù, but there is no option to process these sessions in background - only foreground execution is possible.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Unable to Execute ‚ÄúAdvance Return for Tax on Sales/Pu...
entry.content:
This is standard system behaviour in S/4HANA Public Cloud.

The Fiori app Batch Input Sessions in My Area only allows foreground execution for security and architectural reasons, and this cannot be changed or customized.

In S/4HANA Cloud, all background processing must be handled through the ‚ÄúSchedule Tax Jobs‚Äù app instead.

To automate the GST report and related postings in background:

Open the app Schedule Tax Jobs.

Choose the template ‚ÄúAdvance Return for Tax on Sales/Purchases‚Äù.

Enter the same selection parameters used in your manual run.

Schedule the job for immediate or periodic execution.

This approach ensures that the system automatically generates and posts the tax return data without requiring manual batch input processing.

entry.title: Re: How to change fixed Indicator in Schedule Line in Sch...
entry.content:
The standard BAPI BAPI_SCHEDULE_MAINTAIN is designed for maintaining delivery schedules in Scheduling Agreements (ME38) but does not expose the ‚ÄúFixed Indicator‚Äù field (EKET-FIXKZ) for update. This is a known limitation.

Since there is no standard BAPI exposes EKET-FIXKZ, implement a custom wrapper function module around standard logic and read the schedule line (EKET). Update FIXKZ using CALL FUNCTION ‚ÄòME_UPDATE_SCHEDULE_LINE‚Äô or direct update via BAPI with enhancement or Use BAdI ME_PROCESS_SCHED or user exit EXIT_SAPMM06E_012.

entry.title: Data Quality with Artificial Intelligence (AI)
entry.content:
Utilizing AI for Data Quality:

  • AI capabilities do a great job when it comes to automating data capture, identifying duplicated, corrupted, or missing data pieces, detecting and minimizing errors, and assessing data relevance.
  • AI-powered predictive analytics may help identify potential flaws in data migration scenarios and help prevent them. Some cutting-edge data management platforms already harness the power of AI technologies to ensure hassle-free and efficient data quality management. 
  • One of the biggest advantages of artificial intelligence is that the AI-backed systems and technologies of the present day can help gather and organise humungous volumes of data which are not possible to comprehend manually. This is a huge plus point for organisations that deal with such large amounts of data, as well as for those that offer data management solutions and services, like SAP and its partners

 

AI capabilities within Data Quality:

Applications of AI in data quality management, including data cleansing, matching, deduplication, and enrichment:

Data Cleansing: AI algorithms can identify consistent data patterns, thereby identify data anomalies, correct data errors, missing values. Machine learning models can learn from historical data patterns to predict and fill any missing information.

Data Matching and Deduplication: AI techniques, such as fuzzy matching and clustering algorithms, can identify and merge duplicate records, even when they are not exact matches. This helps in maintaining a single, accurate version of each data entity.

Data Enrichment: AI can enhance data by integrating additional information from external sources. For example, machine learning models can analyse customer data to predict demographic attributes or purchasing behaviour, enriching the existing dataset with valuable insights.

 

Predictive Data Quality Monitoring: AI can continuously monitor data quality in real-time, using predictive analytics to identify potential issues before they become critical. This proactive approach helps in maintaining high data quality standards throughout the migration process.

SAP offers AI Infrastructure and tools like SAP AI Core & SAP AI Launchpad for an unified AI consumption and lifecycle management of all types of AI scenarios. The management of operations of AI scenarios such as versioning, training, deployment and serving is provided through AI Launchpad.

SAP AI Core:

SAP AI Core service on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP).  SAP AI Core is a service within the SAP Business Technology Platform. It seamlessly integrates with SAP solutions, allowing any AI function to be easily implemented using open-source frameworks. SAP AI Core supports full lifecycle management of AI scenarios. Handles large volume of data. Can be configured for open-source machine learning frameworks. Users can access generative AI capabilities through the generative AI hub.

SAP AI Core lets you make data-driven decisions confidently and efficiently. It handles large volumes of data and offers scalable machine learning capabilities to automate tasks. SAP AI Core includes preconfigured SAP solutions and supports open-source machine learning (ML) frameworks.

SAP AI Core allows you to experiment with and utilize natural language prompts with a variety of generative AI models in the generative AI hub.

 

Features

Generative AI hub

Choose from a selection of generative AI models for prompt experimentation and prompt lifecycle management.

Execute pipelines

Execute pipelines as a batch job, for example, to preprocess or train your models, or perform batch inference.

Serve inference requests

Deploy –∞ trained machine learning model as a Web service to serve inference requests of trained models with high performance.

Manage the AI scenario lifecycle

Manage your ML artifacts and workflows, such as model training, metrics tracking, data, models, and model deployments via a uniform API lifecycle.

Benefit from multitenancy support

Use this service in tenant-aware applications. Implement multi-tenant services to segregate your AI assets and executions to isolate your tenants within SAP AI Core.

 

 

Architectural Overview

  • The main components we will use for the setup are:
  • 1. SAP AI Launchpad: Graphical interface to manage AI Core connections, executions, and logs.
  • 2. SAP HANA Database: SAP technology for materialized tables. As of now, there is no straight connection from SAP Data Sphere to AI Core, you need HANA to manage the materialization of the data.
  • 3. GCP Artifact Registry: A private container registry to store Docker images. (AI Core has native Docker Hub support, but Azure Container Registry and other services also work.)
  • 4. GitHub repository: Our code repository of choice, but some services such as BitBucket or GitLab are also supported.

 

Architecture Overview

  1. SAP Build Apps: Serves as the front-end development platform for crafting intuitive user interfaces
  2. SAP AI Core: Acts as the robust runtime engine that executes AI workloads and delivers foundation model capabilities
  3. BTP Destination: Functions as the middleware layer that securely connects Build Apps to AI Core, ensuring smooth and scalable integration.

The integration flow works as follows:

Users engage with the application through the intuitive SAP Build Apps interface. When an input is submitted, it is seamlessly transmitted via BTP Destinations to SAP AI Core, which orchestrates the request. AI Core then processes the input using the powerful GPT-4o model hosted on Azure OpenAI. Once the AI generates a response, the result is returned through the same secure channel and elegantly displayed within the Build Apps interface for the user.

 

 

Prerequisites

  1. SAP BTP account (free tier)
  2. Access to SAP AI Core with sap-internal or extended service plan
  3. SAP Build Apps subscription
  4. SAP AI Launchpad subscription

Step 1: Setting Up Your SAP BTP Environment

Enable Required Services or Applications

  1. Navigate to your SAP BTP Global Account
  2. Go to Instances and Subscriptions section
  3. Search for and enable these applications:
    • AI Launchpad
    • AI Core
    • Build Apps

Subscribe to SAP Build Apps 

 

Related Information

Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core

AI API Overview

SAP AI Launchpad

SAP AI Core ToolKit

SAP AI Launchpad

SAP AI Launchpad is a multitenant software as a service-SaaS application on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) that serves as a central hub for managing AI use cases and generative AI capabilities across various AI runtimes like SAP AI Core via the Generative AI hub.

Its architecture features the Launchpad itself, which connects to multiple AI runtime instances, the Generative AI Hub for managing prompts and LLMs, and the AI API that standardizes the management of AI scenarios across different back-end systems

 

The following features are available for SAP AI Launchpad:

Integrate with AI runtime instances Add connections to one or more AI runtime instances and switch between them to carry out further actions.

Work with resource groups of SAP AI Core Access your resource groups from your SAP AI Core runtime and perform actions only on the AI assets that they contain (for example, models, executions, and deployments).

Manage the lifecycle of Gen AI prompts Access the Generative AI Hub and manage the lifecycle of your prompts. The Generative AI Hub includes prompt experimentation, prompt lifecycle management, and administrative tools.

Manage the lifecycle of AI use cases Explore and manage the lifecycle of all your AI use cases. The lifecycle includes training and deploying AI models to generate endpoints for online predictions

Access statistics on your use cases View statistics about your AI use cases (scenarios) and how they are consumed. By analyzing these statistics, you can better estimate your computing needs for your AI runtimes. Manage administration for SAP AI Core

Manage administration tasks for your SAP AI Core runtime, such as the authentications required in your AI workflows.

Core Components

  • SAP AI Launchpad: The multitenant SaaS application providing the user interface for managing AI use cases and resources. 
  • AI Runtimes (e.g., SAP AI Core): The underlying services that host and execute AI models and workloads. SAP AI Launchpad connects to these runtimes to manage their assets. 
  • Generative AI Hub: A component integrated with SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad for managing and experimenting with generative AI models and prompts. 
  • AI API: A standardized interface that enables consistent AI lifecycle management (scenario management) across different runtimes, regardless of the technology (e.g., SAP-based or partner-provided). 

Key Architectural Aspects

  1. Centralized Management: SAP AI Launchpad acts as a single pane of glass to oversee and manage AI use cases, models, and resources across various instances of AI runtimes.
  2. Runtime Agnosticism: It can connect to multiple AI runtime instances, such as SAP AI Core, and allows users to switch between them for different tasks, offering flexibility in deploying AI workloads.
  3. Lifecycle Management: The platform simplifies the end-to-end lifecycle of AI models, from training and evaluation to deployment and monitoring, ensuring consistency and control.
  4. Generative AI Integration: It provides access to the Generative AI Hub, which includes tools for prompt management, experimentation, and lifecycle management of large language models (LLMs).
  5. AI API for Standardization: The AI API provides a consistent interface for managing AI scenarios on diverse runtime environments, abstracting away the complexities of different underlying infrastructures.
  6. Scalability: Being a SaaS application on SAP BTP, it benefits from the platform's scalability, allowing businesses to manage growing AI initiatives

 

Overview of SAP AI Launchpad and SAP AI Core (as the AI Runtime)

 

Related Information

Using SAP AI Launchpad

Other AI Tools - Microsoft Co-Pilot Pro

 

Applications of AI under SAP Machine learning Ops where is it used -

Productization ‚Äì If you refer stages, it is Data management AI Exploration ‚Äì AI exploration happens under Jupiter notebook, Python and so on.  But in SAP context, tooling like Python or Business Application Studio which is our integrated development environment (IDE) in BTP hub.

Productionization, SAP Core from run time engine monitoring capabilities or AI use case.

Feature engineering there are many tools but under Product ML ops life cycle management and ML ops platform SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad realistic helps to monitor these models and how you can modify

How SAP AI tools help enterprise customers ‚Äì

AI launchpad is not only for customers or partners but with internal enterprise customers ‚Äì stakeholders like in S/4 Ariba, SuccessFactors or in Concur, which underlying runs from SAP perspective on SAP AI core.

The other side is enterprise customers so specific user case cant use, but in SAP landscape context, need to implement in SAP landscape under SAP AI core launchpad.

 

Pre-requisites needed for AI Project, Productionization of AI use cases:

Data management layer or a constructive DM pipeline with all experiments performed under AI exploration phase along with following-

  1. Environment which gives the option to reproduce.
  2. Data management data changes tracking mechanism and ways to evaluate these.
  3. Docker and Kubernetes environment from Infrastructure perspective.
  4. Guidelines and principles perspective, incorporation of git ops principle into the processes and source code and pipelines.
  5. AP AI core which is what you need is providing the code and environment where this has to run (e.g., Python or Java depends on use case) and syncing to the GitHub repository

Scaling AI requires standardization of processes and tools-

AI Productionization ‚Äì AI scalable technologies to deploy manage and integrate AI scenarios.

Unified Data management to capture real time value from different types of data and to fuel AI solutions.

AI Exploration and Modelling

 

When to use these AI core or AI launchpad?

Good to understand, what we have in the portfolio and the scope.  We have SAP AI Business surfaces, due to which, Test Use cases are easy to use in order to set the Ariba, SuccessFactors, S/4 Concur which have embedded AI scenarios and AI Business services.

But, in case of enterprise to the industry, then we need to be able to establish SAP connectivity in SAP context and then run on SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad.

  • AI Core is the engine (where the work is done), and AI Launchpad is the dashboard (where the work is managed and monitored).
  • AI Core is where the actual logic and profile tasks run, can be considered processor.  AI Launchpad is the dashboard, where tasks running under AI Core is managed and monitored.

For SAP Data Quality Profiling, here‚Äôs when to use each ‚Äì

  1. Use SAP AI Core for the actual execution, data format checks and run the actual data profiling logic and data analysis at scale.
  2. AI core is where you define and execute the custom code (e.g., Python or R Scripts to perform analytical tasks like ‚Äì
    1. Calculating descriptive statistics for data fields (min, max, mean).
    2. Measuring data completeness (percentage of non-null values).
    3. Determining data uniqueness (identifying duplicates).
    4. Analysing data consistency and format validity.
    5. Identifying outliers and anomalies in your SAP data.
  • AI Launchpad is where the profiling reports are managed and review the results of the data anomalies.

Triggering the execution of data profiling workflow in AI Core

Monitor the job progress, check logs and ensure profiling task runs successfully.

Reviewing Outputs: Once the AI Core job is complete, the Launchpad is your centralized place to view the resulting data quality reports and metrics (which are the artifacts generated by the AI Core execution). This allows a business analyst or data steward to review the profile without needing to interact with the underlying technical infrastructure.

As the predecessor to Data Quality checks, the Data should be profiled to identifying missing values, duplicates, and inconsistencies, ensuring that only high-quality data is processed

  • Data Quality Dimensions used to access Data Quality: 

 

 Dimensions

Description

Example.

Accuracy

Extent to which data objects correctly represent the real-world values for which they are designed

A material must have a price

Completeness

Extent to which data is not missing

An order is not complete without a payment method

Conformity

Extent to which data conforms to a specified format

Created date must be in the format YYYY/MM/DD

Consistency

Extent to which distinct data instances provide non-conflicting information about the same underlying object

The salary range for level 3 employees must be between $40,000 and $50,000

Integrity

Extent to which data is not missing important relationship linkages

The date for placing an order must be valid

Timeliness

Extent to which data is sufficiently up to date for the task at hand

Christmas lights are in stock by December

Uniqueness

Extent to which the data has unique with no duplicates

Customer#, Vendor# etc. need to be unique

 

  • High-volume data processing: It's designed to handle large amounts of data from SAP applications to create robust AI models. 
  • Integration with SAP applications: It helps to seamlessly embed and operationalize AI capabilities directly into other SAP solutions. 
  • Monitoring and Governance: You want to monitor job status, logs, inference metrics, and track deployments for governance and compliance. 
  • Accessing Generative AI: It includes a generative AI hub for prompt engineering, lifecycle management, and interacting with pre-built generative AI models.

 

  • Integration:
  • Since data profiling is an intensive data preparation step, we use AI Core to orchestrate the pipeline that connects to your SAP data sources (like SAP HANA Cloud or SAP Datasphere) by leveraging SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) as a unified platform to pull the data and run the profiling jobs.
  • Data Privacy / Security Considerations:
  • We can use BTP to call a 3rd party hosted model on Azure, AWS, or OpenAI.
  • AWS Bedrock is an A.I. service offered by Amazon and they clearly state that it is secure and private and Customers can use Bedrock, in compliance with SAP GDPR.

 

End-to-End Architecture, High Level Flow:

Below framework depicts the high level architecture and flow incorporating data privacy / security covering the code interface

entry.title: Re: PCR for PF Calculation Using Processed Basic
entry.content:
You have made a minor change to the Operations of PCR Z023 for ESG * and WT 1000, but I was suggesting that the change should be made in ESG 3 and WT 1000.

 

First, you should not need to query Processing Class 20 for WT 1000 since it has only one return value (3) That VWTCL 20 Operation may be required for WT ****, but should not be for WT 1000.   Only Operations ADDWT&ZBVE, ADDWTE* and ADDCU are required.

Next, make sure that Function PRINT is placed in your Payroll schema after PCR Z023 but before PCR ZREC so that you could confirm that your Temporary Variable is created correctly. 

Last, do a Payroll Simulation for one PERNR, with the "Display Log" box checked, and drill down into that Log to see how WT 1000 is processed in PCRs Z023, Z011 and ZREC (and post the screen capture of that processing).

entry.title: Re: User ID for IAS users
entry.content:
Hello @dyaryura  Hello @MatthiasL 

Thanks again for the helpful discussions!

I still need some clarification on the technical setup of Global User ID  for example SAC especially how it works with IPS and SSO

We provision users from Entra ID ‚Üí IAS ‚Üí SAC. The Global User ID is automatically created and assigned to each user in IAS.

I'm not exactly sure how to implement this Global User ID in a Cloud Application. I have two main ideas (options) and need help deciding which is the correct and recommended way.

Option 1: UUID in a Custom SAC Attribute, SSO via Custom SAML Mapping

  • User Provisioning ( Target System - SAC)

              The Global User ID ($['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:User']['userUuid']) is provisioned into a custom attribute in SAC. For example:

  

{

 "sourcePath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:User']['userUuid']",

  "optional": true,

  "targetPath": "$.attributes.customGlobalUserID"

}

The custom attribute ‚ÄûcustomGlobalUserID‚Äú will be created in SAC.

  • SAC SSO Setup:
    • In SAC for "User Attribute to map to your identity provider," I select "Custom SAML User Mapping  and choose  the attribute ‚ÄûcustomGlobalUserID‚Äú
    • The "USER ID" field in SAC would be filled with the "Login Name"  Value from IAS (e.g., testname).

 

Option 2: GUID Directly into SAC's "USER ID" Field, SSO via USER ID Mapping

  • User Provisioning (Target System - SAC):

                       The Global User ID ($['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:User']['userUuid']) is provisioned directly into "USER ID" field in SAC. For example:

  {

  "sourcePath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:User']['userUuid']",

  "targetPath": "$['urn:sap:params:scim:schemas:extension:sac:2.0:user-custom-parameters']['userName']"

}

 

  • SAC SSO Setup:
    • For "User Attribute to map to your identity provider," I will select "USER ID."

 

I haven't fully understood the implementation yet and would really appreciate your help.

Thank you in advance!!!

Best regards

entry.title: Unavailability of Released CDS view for Warehouse task - Internal moment
entry.content:
Requirement - Pack outbound delivery - HU Based - GI Label trigger with left over stock

We are printing the GI label with reference to the Outbound delivery number from SAP to 3rd Party system while using the App Pack outbound deliveries with reference to the Outbound delivery number. It is a Warehouse task and getting confirmed, but the warehouse task details do not contain the reference document of the Outbound delivery number in any CDS Views or SAP standard tables.

However, we found the SAP standard CDS view "I_EWM_handlingunititem", which contains the Outbound Delivery details. But this is not yet released in the 2508 version.  

Technical Design: We are using an event-based triggering process for the above requirement. Below is the Event used for Warehouse Internal moment(Leftover Stock) Labels.

Event - sap/s4/beh/WarehouseOrder/TaskConfirmed/v1

Once the packing is done in the app "Pack Outbound Delivery", the Warehouse Task event gets triggered. Based on the Warehouse task, we need to obtain all the required details from the Outbound Delivery. So the challenge is that we don't have a released CDS View(I_EWM_handlingunititem) to find the Outbound delivery number linkage from packed outbound delivery warehouse task details. We need a workaround solution as this requirement is crucial for the Business to operate and print the labels in the warehouse.

entry.title: Has Devtoberfest just proved that ABAP is in fact dead?
entry.content:
I'm sorry to say SAP, Devtoberfest: You have lost me.

You say Monday is for ABAP, but in my book table/view entities, annotations, projections, service definitions, service bindings, analytics, joule etc. is not really ABAP. 

A few years ago Thursday was for analytics and AI, but today I saw an "ABAP" session about "Explore the Latest Updates in ABAP CDS". You call it "ABAP" CDS, but this session contained stuff like joule and analytics (used to be Thursday stuff) - i didn't see one single real ABAP command. 

And it is the same for all ABAP Sessions. So far I would say that 80% of the Monday stuff does not belong in my ABAP book. The only session I really could relate to so far was " Custom code development and transformation for Clean Core in SAP S/4HANA".

Now you even put ABAP as a minor part in a corner of Build. As an ABAP developer that really makes me feel devaluated.

Of course you have all the right in the world to use your brands as you like and rebrand when you like,  but I don't really understand what you want to achieve by calling CDS views for ABAP CDS and say RAP is ABAP when it is not really? 

Someone will probably argue that the new declarative annotation language is embedded in ABAP (the cloud version), but does that make it ABAP? It somehow reminds me of the Tower of Babel.

Best Regards
Thomas Madsen Nielsen

entry.title: Using First Name and Last Name field in infotype 2 as preferrred names
entry.content:
My HR clients want to use the Last name (NACHN) and First name (VORNA) fields as the chosen (preferred) names.  Alternatively, they would like to use the Known As (RUFNM) and Birth Name (NAME2) fields to track Legal Names.    

The reason for this request is because the legal names will be on an absolutely "need to know" basis.  Those who are privy to this information (security, pay, etc) will have access to the legal names via PA20 as they do now otherwise employees will only be known across the board by their preferred names.   Using these two fields as the preferred names would ultimately mean that we wouldn't have to change reports, reconfigure ENAME field, etc.

Important to note that we have an external payroll system which does not integrate with ECC,.  I'd like to know your thoughts on this solution?   I do know that the best practice is to create custom fields but I'd like to know your thoughts or opinions.  

 

Thank you!!!

entry.title: The Ultimate Guide to Banking bg software Investment
entry.content:
How do you Unlock financial solutions for your projects ! #FinancialInstruments #BusinessGrowth

 

 

The Ultimate Guide to SAP S/4HANA Transformation: Strategy, Processes, Change, and ROI

Introduction for All Users

Welcome to your comprehensive guide to understanding and navigating an SAP S/4HANA transformation. Whether you are an end-user learning a new system, a key user helping to design it, a consultant implementing it, or a manager making the business case for it, this guide is for you.

For decades, companies have relied on Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) systems to run their core operations. However, the business landscape has changed dramatically. We now operate in a globalized, hyper-connected, real-time world. The old, clunky, and siloed systems of the past are no longer sufficient.

What is SAP S/4HANA? Think of a traditional company with separate departments: finance has its own ledgers, manufacturing has its own production schedules, and sales has its own customer lists. In the past, getting these systems to talk to each other was a nightmare of custom-coded connections‚Äîa complex mess often called "interapplication spaghetti."

SAP S/4HANA is a modern, intelligent ERP system designed to eliminate this complexity. It's built on an advanced in-memory database (HANA), which makes it incredibly fast. More importantly, it acts as a single "digital core" for the entire enterprise, providing one source of truth for all data. This means that when a salesperson enters an order, the finance and manufacturing departments see it instantly. This enables real-time decision-making, streamlined processes, and a more agile, responsive business.

This guide will walk you through the entire transformation journey, from the initial strategic decision-making to modeling new business processes, managing the human side of change, and realizing a quantifiable return on investment.

Part 1: The Strategic Imperative for ERP Transformation

The decision to move to a new ERP system like SAP S/4HANA is not merely a technical upgrade; it is a fundamental business decision driven by significant external and internal pressures.

The Modern Business Landscape: From Value Chains to Value Networks

The traditional, linear concept of a "value chain"‚Äîwhere a company takes in raw materials, adds value through internal processes, and sells a finished product‚Äîis outdated. We now operate in a digital ecosystem or a "value network."

This network includes:

  • Suppliers and their suppliers: Creating deep, collaborative supply chains.
  • Partners: Co-developing products and services.
  • Customers: Who are more informed and demand personalized experiences.
  • Global Competition: Forcing companies to be more efficient and innovative.

In this environment, success depends on speed, agility, and information transparency. The ability to act locally while thinking globally is paramount. A business must be able to sense and respond to market shifts in real-time. Legacy systems, with their batch processes and data silos, create "information latency"‚Äîa delay between a business event happening and the organization being able to act on it. In the modern economy, this latency is a critical competitive disadvantage.

The Problem with Legacy Systems: "Interapplication Spaghetti"

Many established organizations run on a complex patchwork of legacy systems, packaged applications from different vendors, and homegrown solutions. Integrating these disparate systems has traditionally been a major challenge.

The common approach was to build custom point-to-point interfaces for each pair of applications that needed to communicate. For a company with dozens of applications, the result is a staggering mess of connections, aptly named "interapplication spaghetti."

This architecture is characterized by:

  • High Cost: Gartner Group estimated that up to 30% of the cost of implementing a major application was spent on building these interfaces, with even more spent on their ongoing maintenance.
  • Brittleness: The integration is fragile. When one application is upgraded or replaced, dozens of custom interfaces can break, requiring extensive and costly rework.
  • Data Inconsistency: With data being copied and moved between systems, it is often out-of-sync and out-of-date across the enterprise. There is no single source of truth.
  • Lack of Agility: The complexity makes it incredibly slow, expensive, and risky to introduce new applications or change business processes.

The "zero-latency enterprise" is the goal: moving information from application to application with near-zero delay to streamline business processes, reduce costs, and respond instantly to market demands. Interapplication spaghetti makes this impossible. SAP S/4HANA, with its integrated digital core, is the architectural solution to this problem.

Building the Business Case for SAP S/4HANA

While the technical and strategic benefits are clear, any major IT investment requires a solid financial justification. We can adapt the classic Return on Investment (ROI) model used for technology projects to build a compelling business case for S/4HANA.

The core of the analysis is comparing the projected costs and benefits of implementing S/4HANA against the alternative‚Äîcontinuing with the legacy landscape and building more point-to-point interfaces.

ROI Calculation Methodology

We can calculate the first-year ROI using a simple, powerful formula:

ROI=Cost of S/4HANA ImplementationFirst Year Savings‚Äã

Let's break down the components:

  1. Cost of S/4HANA Implementation: This includes all the one-time costs to get the system live.
  • Software Licenses: The license fee for the S/4HANA software.
  • Infrastructure: Costs for servers (cloud or on-premise).
  • Implementation Services: The cost of system integrators or internal project teams for installation, configuration, and data migration.
  • Training: Costs for training administrative personnel, developers, and end-users.
  • Change Management: Costs associated with communication, stakeholder management, and organizational readiness programs.
  1. First Year Savings: This is the most critical part of the calculation. It represents the cost avoidance and efficiency gains achieved by using S/4HANA.
  • First Year Savings = (A) Estimated Cost of Development without S/4HANA - (B) Actual Cost of Development with S/4HANA
    • (A) Estimated Cost of Development without S/4HANA: This is a projection of the costs your business would incur over the next year if you didn't implement S/4HANA. Experienced project managers and IT leaders must estimate the hours required for all planned projects (e.g., launching a new product, integrating a new sales channel, generating new reports) using the old, point-to-point method. This includes hours for design, custom coding, testing, and deployment.
    • (B) Actual Cost of Development with S/4HANA: This is the labor cost of the project team implementing S/4HANA. While this is a significant cost, it is an investment that creates a reusable, scalable platform.

A Hypothetical ROI Calculation Example

Category

Amount

(A) Estimated Cost of Development without S/4HANA (1 Year)

‚Ç¨5,000,000

entry.title: Designer Installation: Step-by-Step Guide for SAP Data Services Client Tool üíª
entry.content:
Make sure you download Designer setup with the same version as your Data Services Job Server machine, which consequently makes the Designer certified with the CMS (BI/IPS) version.

In case you have BI/IPS application or client installed on this machine, make sure it is also certified with your Designer application, even if it is not being used as CMS Server:

  • 3322026- Can BOE/BI/IPS Platform Client Tools and Designer Client Tool coexist in the same machine? - SAP Data Services

Download Designer using the steps below:

  • Software Center - SAP for Me > SUPPORT PACKAGES & PATCHES > By Alphabetical Index (A-Z) > D > SAP DATA SERVICES > SAP DATA SERVICES 4.x > SAP DS CLIENT TOOLS 4.x > Select a compatible version and download it

NOTE: This post is using Designer Client 2025 (14.4.0.165) as screenshots reference.

INSTALLATION STEPS üöÄ

After downloading the setup, let's start the installation.

  1. Run the installer as Administrator user to avoid any problems.
  2. Make sure all the prerequisites which are Critical type are on Succeeded status and click on Next.

  3. Read and select the "I accept the License Agreement". Click on Next.



  4. Add the same valid License Key as your Data Services application server and click on Next:



    Additional content:
    1977090- Is a new license key required when upgrading to Data Services 4.2, 4.3 or 2025?

  5. Confirm the installation path and click on Next.



  6. Confirm the %DS_COMMON_DIR% directory of SAP Data Services Designer and click on Next:



  7. Select any additional language and click on Next:

  8. Select "Skip CMS", since this is the Designer Client tool installation and not the application server and click on Next:



  9. Uncheck the "Data Services Server" box and click on Next:



  10. Select "Skip Configuration", since this is your Designer client machine and the DSConfig.txt files will be under your Job Server machine. Click on Next.



  11. Start the installation. Click Next:



  12. Installation is complete. Click on Finish.



  13. Reboot machine is required. Only click on "Yes" after confirming that you can restart your machine right now.



  14. Your Designer should be accessible:

 

Additional content:

  • "The base keycode for the Data Services platform was not found or has expired. Obtain a valid keycode and use the License Manager to update your installation. (BODI-1116106)" after Designer installation / upgrade:

    Check the KBA below:
    1395080- How to install or maintain License/Product keys - SAP Data Services
  • For SAP Data Services 2025, missing ncs.dll:
    3641815 - Designer fails to launch with keycode error - SAP Data Services 2025

  • For SDK Failure when accessing Designer tool: 
    It might be compatibility between your Designer tool and the CMS Server (BI/IPS), but also bi-directionally communication between Designer <-> CMS Server.
    Make sure you can ping and telnet from Designer to the CMS Server and vice versa (CMS Server to Designer).
    In case it is compatible and telnet/ping works bi-directionally, check and apply the KBA below:

    2450650 - Logon failed to the specified system. Check system name, port number, user name, password, authentication method, and try again. Additional information: <Session: SDK failure>. - SAP Data Services
  • Designer client is slow:
    3034996- SAP Data Services Designer slow performance - SAP Data Services

 

üåüIf you have any questions or need assistance, feel free to reach out to SAP Support and search under our Knowledge Base!

üìåIf you found this helpful or interesting, I would really appreciate a 'Kudo' to let me know! Your feedback means a lot. üòä

entry.title: Re: Delivery adress of plant not taking in account
entry.content:
Hi,

To ensure the system derives the correct delivery address, the following configuration steps must be performed and verified:

1. SSCUI 105933 ‚Äì Maintain Storage Location

  • For Plant and Storage Location , maintain the delivery (ship-to) address:
  • Ensure all fields (street, postal code, city, region, and country) are completed. This configuration defines the address that the system uses as the delivery address for purchase orders.

 

2. SSCUI 102657 ‚Äì Set Warehouse Address

  • Go to SSCUI 102657 ‚Äì Set Warehouse Address.
  • For Warehouse, maintain the same delivery address as above. This ensures warehouse-related logistics documents (such as inbound/outbound deliveries) use the same physical address.

 

3. SSCUI 102125 ‚Äì Define Shipping Point

  • Go to SSCUI 102125 ‚Äì Define Shipping Point.
  • For Shipping Points, maintain the correct delivery address corresponding to the warehouse location. Consistent address data ensures proper address determination in delivery-related processes.

 

4. Manage Business Partner Master Data

  • Open the ‚ÄúManage Business Partner Master Data‚Äù app.
  • For BP, create and maintain:
    • BILL-TO address: XYZ
    • SHIP-TO address: ABC
  • Assign address types correctly and ensure roles are consistent with supplier functions. These addresses are used for communication and output (not for internal PO address determination).

 

Validate:

  1. Create a new Purchase Order.
  2. Use Plant and Storage Location.
  3. Check the Delivery Address tab ‚Äî it should now display the storage location address instead of the bill-to address.
  4. Test PO output to confirm that:
    • Delivery Address on the form corresponds to the storage location (ship-to).
    • Invoice Address corresponds to the bill-to address from the Business Partner.

Thanks and regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Reconciliation Accounts Payable after Advanced Foreig...
entry.content:
App "Manage Supplier Line Items" contains the information of the entry view table BSEG.

The advanced foreign currency valuation postings are only updated in the ACDOCA table - Posting in General Ledger Only and not the BSEG table.


as referenced in blog

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/advanced-foreign-currency-valuation-in-s-4hana-cloud-cloud-erp/ba-p/13562579


"Document posted through this will not be seen in Manage Supplier Line Items or Manage Customer Line Items app. But it will be seen in Display Line Items in General Ledger app."


In classical valuation it is also not the case that the valuation posting is made directly on the supplier/customer, it is made to a balance sheet adjustment account and offsetting gain/loss account. Customers for classical valuation can use the Balance Sheet/Incoming statement to review balances on customer/Supplier account with the adjustment account in same grouping.

In the advanced valuation there is no posting to the balance sheet adjustment account for the customer/Supplier rather there is posting on account itself.

Likewise you can use the App Balance Sheet/Income Statement to review balance on account.

In the app Display General Ledger Line Items you can use filter Business Transaction types to filter/distinguish sources on account. For example Business transaction type RFCV is used for Foreign currency Valuation.

entry.title: Re: Streamline Data Migration from SAP ECC to SAP S/4HANA: Selective Data Transition with Time-Slice
entry.content:
Hello @matthiasstegmue 

Our customer is currently running SAP ECC 6.0 and planning a conversion to S/4HANA 2023 or 2025, hosted on RISE with SAP (Private Cloud ERP).

Using the S/4HANA sizing tool, the projected target HANA database size is around 2 TB, which is considered quite large  . Since the customer is not keen on starting a prerequisite and expensive archiving project, we explored the use of SAP Lean System Discovery Tool (SDT).

As shown in the attached screenshot, we have completed the Digital Blueprint phase, and the results are very promising , showing over 50% footprint reduction.

My question is: how should this reduction be interpreted in terms of hardware resources?

We are in the process of building the BOM for the Private Cloud ERP migration, and we need to come up with realistic sizing numbers , specifically:

  • Expected HANA memory size

  • Expected HANA disk size

Would it be correct to assume that the 50% footprint reduction directly translates into a ~1 TB target HANA database size (i.e., 50% of the original 2 TB estimate)?

Or is it not that straightforward, and the only accurate way to estimate the target HANA database size using Lean SDT is to perform a full sandbox conversion run?

Any insight or reference from those who have done this in practice would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks,
